messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 46 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Channels of Small Log-Ratio Leakage and Characterization of Two-Party Differentially Private Computation An extended abstract of this work appeared in TCC 2019 [24]

Paper Abstract: Abstract Consider a ppt two-party protocol Î =(ğ– ,ğ–¡)Î ğ– ğ–¡\Pi=(\mathsf{A},\mathsf{B}) in which the parties get no private inputs and obtain outputs Oğ– ,Oğ–¡âˆˆ{0,1}superscriptğ‘‚ğ– superscriptğ‘‚ğ–¡01O^{\mathsf{A}},O^{\mathsf{B}}\in\left\{0,1\right\}, and let Vğ– superscriptğ‘‰ğ– V^{\mathsf{A}} and Vğ–¡superscriptğ‘‰ğ–¡V^{\mathsf{B}} denote the partiesâ€™ individual views. Protocol Î Î \Pi has Î±ğ›¼\alpha-agreement if Prâ¡[Oğ– =Oğ–¡]=12+Î±Prsuperscriptğ‘‚ğ– superscriptğ‘‚ğ–¡12ğ›¼\Pr[O^{\mathsf{A}}=O^{\mathsf{B}}]=\tfrac{1}{2}+\alpha. The leakage of Î Î \Pi is the amount of information a party obtains about the event {Oğ– =Oğ–¡}superscriptğ‘‚ğ– superscriptğ‘‚ğ–¡\left\{O^{\mathsf{A}}=O^{\mathsf{B}}\right\}; that is, the leakage Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon is the maximum, over ğ–¯âˆˆ{ğ– ,ğ–¡}ğ–¯ğ– ğ–¡\mathsf{P}\in\left\{\mathsf{A},\mathsf{B}\right\}, of the distance between Vğ–¯|Oğ– =Oğ–¡evaluated-atsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ–¯superscriptğ‘‚ğ– superscriptğ‘‚ğ–¡V^{\mathsf{P}}|_{O^{\mathsf{A}}=O^{\mathsf{B}}} and Vğ–¯|Oğ– â‰ Oğ–¡evaluated-atsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ–¯superscriptğ‘‚ğ– superscriptğ‘‚ğ–¡V^{\mathsf{P}}|_{O^{\mathsf{A}}\neq O^{\mathsf{B}}}. Typically, this distance is measured in statistical distance, or, in the computational setting, in computational indistinguishability. For this choice, Wullschleger [TCC â€™09] showed that if Ïµâ‰ªÎ±much-less-thanitalic-Ïµğ›¼\epsilon\ll\alpha then the protocol can be transformed into an OT protocol. We consider measuring the protocol leakage by the log-ratio distance (which was popularized by its use in the differential privacy framework). The log-ratio distance between X,Yğ‘‹ğ‘ŒX,Y over domain Î©Î©\Omega is the minimal Ïµâ‰¥0italic-Ïµ0\epsilon\geq 0 for which, for every vâˆˆÎ©ğ‘£Î©v\in\Omega, logâ¡Prâ¡[X=v]Prâ¡[Y=v]âˆˆ[âˆ’Ïµ,Ïµ]Prğ‘‹ğ‘£Prğ‘Œğ‘£italic-Ïµitalic-Ïµ\log\frac{\Pr[X=v]}{\Pr[Y=v]}\in[-\epsilon,\epsilon]. In the computational setting, we use computational indistinguishability from having log-ratio distance Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon. We show that a protocol with (noticeable) accuracy Î±âˆˆÎ©â€‹(Ïµ2)ğ›¼Î©superscriptitalic-Ïµ2\alpha\in\Omega(\epsilon^{2}) can be transformed into an OT protocol (note that this allows Ïµâ‰«Î±much-greater-thanitalic-Ïµğ›¼\epsilon\gg\alpha). We complete the picture, in this respect, showing that a protocol with Î±âˆˆoâ€‹(Ïµ2)ğ›¼ğ‘œsuperscriptitalic-Ïµ2\alpha\in o(\epsilon^{2}) does not necessarily imply OT. Our results hold for both the information theoretic and the computational settings, and can be viewed as a â€œfine grainedâ€ approach to â€œweak OT amplificationâ€. We then use the above result to fully characterize the complexity of differentially private two-party computation for the XOR function, answering the open question put by Goyal, Khurana, Mironov, Pandey, and Sahai [ICALP â€™16] and Haitner, Nissim, Omri, Shaltiel, and Silbak [FOCS â€™18]. Specifically, we show that for any (noticeable) Î±âˆˆÎ©â€‹(Ïµ2)ğ›¼Î©superscriptitalic-Ïµ2\alpha\in\Omega(\epsilon^{2}), a two-party protocol that computes the XOR function with Î±ğ›¼\alpha-accuracy and Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-differential privacy can be transformed into an OT protocol. This improves upon Goyal et al. that only handle Î±âˆˆÎ©â€‹(Ïµ)ğ›¼Î©italic-Ïµ\alpha\in\Omega(\epsilon), and upon Haitner et al. who showed that such a protocol implies (infinitely-often) key agreement (and not OT). Our characterization is tight since OT does not follow from protocols in which Î±âˆˆoâ€‹(Ïµ2)ğ›¼ğ‘œsuperscriptitalic-Ïµ2\alpha\in o(\epsilon^{2}), and extends to functions (over many bits) that â€œcontainâ€ an â€œembedded copyâ€ of the XOR function.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 46 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 46"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Priced oblivious transfer: How to sell digital goods",
        "The all-or-nothing nature of two-party secure computation",
        "Distributed private data analysis: Simultaneously solving how and what",
        "Non-interactive oblivious transfer and applications",
        "Generalized privacy amplification",
        "Optimal lower bound for differentially private multi-party aggregation",
        "Efficient cryptographic protocols based on noisy channels",
        "Achieving oblivious transfer using weakened security assumptions",
        "Concentrated differential privacy",
        "Calibrating noise to sensitivity in private data analysis",
        "Boosting and differential privacy",
        "A randomized protocol for signing contracts",
        "Foundations of Cryptography â€“ Volume 2: Basic Applications",
        "How to play any mental game or a completeness theorem for protocols with honest majority",
        "On the existence of pseudorandom generators",
        "Accuracy-privacy tradeoffs for two-party differentially private protocols",
        "Do distributed differentially-private protocols require oblivious transfer?",
        "Implementing oblivious transfer using collection of dense trapdoor permutations",
        "A parallel repetition theorem for any interactive argument",
        "On the power of the randomized iterate",
        "Efficiency improvements in constructing pseudorandom generators from one-way functions",
        "Limits on the usefulness of random oracles",
        "Computational two-party correlation",
        "Channels of small log-ratio leakage and characterization of two-party differentially private computation",
        "Completeness in two-party secure computation: A computational view",
        "An efficient parallel repetition theorem",
        "Probability inequalities for sums of bounded random variables",
        "Pseudorandom generators from one-way functions: A simple construction for any hardness",
        "One-way functions are essential for complexity based cryptography",
        "Differentially private multi-party computation: Optimality of non-interactive randomized response",
        "Smooth projective hashing and two-message oblivious transfer",
        "Black-box separations for differentially private protocols",
        "Secret key agreement by public discussion from common information",
        "The limits of two-party differential privacy",
        "Computational differential privacy",
        "Efficient oblivious transfer protocols",
        "On the oblivious-transfer capacity of noisy resources",
        "A framework for efficient and composable oblivious transfer",
        "Assisted common information with an application to secure two-party sampling",
        "How to exchange secrets by oblivious transfer",
        "Randomized response: A survey technique for eliminating evasive answer bias",
        "Zero-error information and applications in cryptography",
        "Oblivious-Transfer Amplification",
        "Oblivious transfer from weak noisy channels",
        "Protocols for secure computations",
        "How to generate and exchange secrets"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 46 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Channels of Small Log-Ratio Leakage and Characterization of Two-Party Differentially Private Computation An extended abstract of this work appeared in TCC 2019 [24], providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
